column1: Where do war generals make decisions? in a think tank
column3: Tank can refer to a large container (e.g., for water or gas), or it can refer to an armored combat vehicle.
column4: The aquarium has a large tank filled with colorful fish.
column5: The army deployed a new tank to the battlefield for protection.

column1: What do you call a fat alien? an extra-cholesterol. ...im so sorry.
column3: Extra can mean additional or in excess, and in entertainment contexts, it often refers to a background actor.
column4: I ordered an extra slice of pizza to share with my friends.
column5: The film production hired an extra for the crowd scene.

column1: Whats the difference between jelly and jam? i cant jelly my dick down a bitches throat.
column3: Jam can refer to a fruit preserve and also to the act of getting stuck or blocked (as in a traffic jam).
column4: She spread jelly on her toast for breakfast.
column5: The car got stuck in a traffic jam on the highway.

column1: I stole a tom cruise movie from the store the other day... it was risky business.
column3: Business can refer to a persons occupation or trade, and it can also mean an event or situation.
column4: She runs a successful business selling handmade jewelry.
column5: Its none of your business what I choose to do with my life.

column1: How does good king wenceslas like his pizza? deep pan, crisp and even
column3: Pan can refer to a cooking implement or a flat container, and it can also denote a wide perspective or view (as in a panoramic view).
column4: She put the brownies in the oven to bake in a square pan.
column5: The mountain vista provided a breathtaking pan of the landscape.
